title: Martin Scorsese compares Marvel films to theme parks again
text:
Martin isn’t a fan of Marvel (Picture: Getty Images)

Martin Scorsese doubled down on his recent criticism of Marvel films, calling them nothing more than ‘amusement parks’ that are taking over cinema.

The acclaimed director spoke at a press conference along with acting heavyweights Al Pacino and Robert De Niro ahead of The Irishman’s screening at the BFI London Film Festival.

Speaking of the multi-million pound movie franchise, he said: ‘As I was saying earlier, it’s not cinema, it’s something else. Whether you go for that or not, it is something else and we shouldn’t be invaded by it.

‘And so that’s a big issue, and we need the theatre owners to step up for that, to allow theatres to show films that are narrative films.’

Earlier this week the director delivered a talk at Bafta’s David Lean lecture in the Royal Opera House on Saturday where he launched into a scathing attack on Marvel, lamenting that ‘theatres have become amusement parks.’

‘Where do young people go to get their films financed now? I have no idea. They are not going to go to a Hollywood studio,’ he told a packed-out hall.

The veteran director accused Marvel movies of taking over cinema (Picture: Rex)

‘And then when you get it made, where is it going to be shown, when the theatres are all being taken over by the theme park films? Theatres have become amusement parks. That is all fine and good but don’t invade everything else in that sense.’

He continued: ‘If you have a child and the child wants to see the picture, what are you going to do? It’s up to you. The audience that sees them now, the fans that see those pictures now, they were raised on pictures like that.

‘The technique is very well done but there is only one Spielberg, there is only one Lucas, James Cameron, it’s a different thing now.

Marvel actors have yet to respond to the director’s comments (Picture: Rex)

‘It’s an invasion, so to speak, in the theatre.’

The 76-year-old – who directed Taxi Driver, Goodfellas and Gangs Of The New York – previously told Empire magazine that he ‘tried’ to watch the Marvel films but he didn’t feel they were ‘cinema.’

‘Honestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks. It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.’

He isn’t the first person to disparage the franchise. Jennifer Aniston claimed Marvel films are ‘diminishing’ cinema.

Explaining her return to television with The Morning Show, she said: ‘You’re seeing what’s available out there and it’s just diminishing and diminishing in terms of, it’s big Marvel movies.

Or things that I’m just not asked to do or really interested living in a green screen.’
